Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Deciphering the seasonal dynamics of multifaceted aerosol-ozone interplay: Implications for air quality management in Eastern China.

AbstractText: We employed an enhanced WRF-Chem to investigate the discrete mechanisms of aerosol-radiation-feedback (ARF), extinction-photochemistry (AEP), and heterogeneous-reactions (AHR) across different seasons in eastern China, aiming to assess the synergistic effects arising from the simultaneous operation of multiple processes on O<sub>3</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub>. Our findings demonstrated that ARF fostered the accumulation of pollutants and moisture, initiating two distinct feedback mechanisms concerning O<sub>3</sub>. The elevation in the NO/NO<sub>2</sub> ratio amplified O<sub>3</sub> consumption. Increased near-surface moisture diminished upper-level cloud formation, thereby enhancing photolysis rates and O<sub>3</sub> photochemical production. The pronounced impact of heightened NO/NO<sub>2</sub> on O<sub>3</sub> led to a decrease of 0.1-2.7 ppb. When decoupled from ARF, AEP led to a more significant reduction in photolysis rates, resulting in declines in both O<sub>3</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub>, except for an anomalous increase observed in summer, with O<sub>3</sub> increasing by 1.6 ppb and PM<sub>2.5</sub> by 2.5 μg m<sup>-3</sup>. The heterogeneous absorption of hydroxides in spring, autumn, and winter predominantly governed the AHR-induced variation of O<sub>3</sub>, leading to a decrease in O<sub>3</sub> by 0.7-1 ppb. Conversely, O<sub>3</sub> variations in summer were primarily dictated by O<sub>3</sub>-sensitive chemistry, with heterogeneous absorption of NO<sub>y</sub> catalyzing a decrease of 2.4 ppb in O<sub>3</sub>. Furthermore, AHR accentuated PM<sub>2.5</sub> by facilitating the formation of fine sulfates and ammonium while impeding nitrate formation. In summer, the collective impact of ARF, AEP, and AHR (ALL) led to a substantial reduction of 6.2 ppb in O<sub>3</sub>, alleviating the secondary oxidation of PM<sub>2.5</sub> and leading to a decrease of 0.3 μg m<sup>-3</sup> in PM<sub>2.5</sub>. Conversely, albeit aerosol substantially depleted O<sub>3</sub> by 0.4-4 ppb through their interactions except for summer, aerosol feedback on PM<sub>2.5</sub> was more pronounced, resulting in a significant increase of 1.7-6.1 μg m<sup>-3</sup> in PM<sub>2.5</sub>. Our study underscored the seasonal disparities in the ramifications of multifaceted aerosol-ozone interplay on air quality.
